title: The MTA's resurrection plan: $51B and a subway up to 125th Street
text:
The more than $40 billion that the proposal contains for New York City’s subways and buses exceeds the entire size of the MTA’s existing, five-year $33 billion capital plan, which runs through the end of 2019. | Getty Images The MTA's resurrection plan: $51B and a subway up to 125th Street

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority hopes to commit $51 billion over the next five years to the resurrection of the region’s mass transit system.

That level of investment appears to be unheard of, and the announcement on Monday came adorned with superlatives.

Story Continued Below

The proposed plan, which presupposes the participation of Mayor Bill de Blasio, the Trump administration and the New York State Legislature, represents “the largest ever in the public transit system,” according to MTA chairman and CEO Pat Foye.

The more than $40 billion that the proposal contains for New York City’s subways and buses exceeds the entire size of the MTA’s existing, five-year $33 billion capital plan, which runs through the end of 2019.

The new plan includes more than $5 billion to make as many as 66 additional subway stations accessible for, “what I believe is the single largest investment of any public agency in accessibility,” Foye said. That investment will mean that stations serving more than 60 percent of subway passengers will be wheelchair accessible.

All of which is more than New York City Transit president Andy Byford had been hoping for.

“I am ecstatically happy,” Byford said Monday. “I mean, this could not be better.”

The plan calls for a $7 billion investment into resignaling portions of six subway lines, which will enable more trains to run along those lines, increasing their capacity. Right now, only the L and 7 lines have modern signaling. They each consistently out-perform the rest of the system.

The plan calls for a $1.6 billion investment in the second phase of the Second Avenue Subway, up to 125th Street, a roughly 1.5-mile extension that’s slated to cost some $6 billion. That cost falls far out of line with comparable systems elsewhere in the world.

“We have to have a longer conversation about the comparisons to other places,” said Janno Lieber, the capital construction chief who will be shepherding the program.

The plan includes $2.3 billion for new buses, 500 of which will be all-electric. There’s also nearly $6 billion for the Long Island Rail Road and nearly $5 billion for Metro-North, including funding that will enable some Metro-North riders to disembark in Penn Station.

Lieber said some projects would likely outlast the plan’s five-year timeline, much as the MTA has yet to spend all of the $33 billion in its existing capital plan. Even so, Foye promised that the authority would not be moving elements from the current plan to the new one in some sort of financial sleight of hand meant to increase the apparent size of the new investment — a prospect some advocates have feared.

“There’s no rollover,” Foye said.

While the program relies on funding from the congestion pricing scheme set to go into effect in 2021, as well as excess revenue from the MTA’s bridges and tunnels, it — crucially — also relies on nearly $11 billion in funding from the Trump administration, $3 billion from the de Blasio administration, and $3 billion from the state. The governor is on board. It’s not clear where the de Blasio and Trump administrations stand.

MTA officials briefed reporters on the capital plan Monday morning. Under the terms of that briefing, reporters were precluded from reaching out to any other parties for comment prior to 1 p.m., when the news embargo would be lifted.

During the briefing, a reporter asked Foye what, if any, discussions the MTA or the governor had had with the de Blasio administration.

“We are meeting with folks from City Hall today,” Foye said. “The numbers that we are discussing are consistent with what the city and the state have done in the past.”

He said the city’s $3 billion would go toward making the subway more accessible to people in wheelchairs, the elderly and caregivers pushing strollers.

The 50-50 split between the city and state is a departure from the past cost-sharing rubric, in which the city promised $2.5 billion and the state promised $8.3 billion. The state and city did split the cost of the much smaller subway stabilization plan, Foye noted.

The Trump administration has shown reluctance toward funding New York infrastructure priorities, though the president did suggest he supported the Second Avenue Subway in a tweet that befuddled local transportation officials.

Foye argued it only makes sense for the Trump administration to fund the MTA, because “these are projects, frankly, of national significance.”

The MTA is still hoping to submit the plan to a state review board for approval by October 1. The MTA board is expected to vote on it later this month.

“This is our vision for what it will take to revitalize the transit system in New York,” Foye said.
description: The proposed plan represents “the largest ever in the public transit system,” according to MTA chairman and CEO Pat Foye.
